Ask HN: Any real US alternatives to Starbucks for a place to work/study?
text:
I wanted to try a new chain to do some work/study/chill at, but realized that Starbucks is about it in Atlanta as far as chains go.

But then I looked a bit deeper and realized that there did not seem to be any real alternatives to Starbucks - for the type of sit-down-for-hours place I was looking for.

So, 'real' in this case means a place with nice, comfortable furniture and an atmosphere that says, "Welcome - stay a while." -- i.e. a real third place.

When I check out Caribou Coffee, for instance, which may be the biggest somewhat-like-Starbucks coffee chain in the US, and it's eh -- I really don't even want to go in. In terms of potential work space welcome, I'd give Starbucks a 6 or 7 and Caribou a 2 or 3. Why? The cheaper, less-comfortable-seeming furniture, seemingly-smaller/tighter footprints, etc. -- the whole vibe is more fast food than I'd prefer.

A place like Panera Bread is interesting-ish, but doesn't quite feel right - like when the lunch rush comes, you feel in the way -- because you probably _are_ in the way -- they do things like set timers on the wifi, etc.

I do have some smaller cafes that I go to -- some might even qualify as small chains (e.g., Dancing Goats) -- but I was kind of surprised to find out that there are no very direct Starbucks competitors for a 'third place' in the US.

Maybe places like Caribou or Philz or whatever will just take 10 more years to try to grab some market share? Or maybe Starbucks has already reached an Amazon-level of super-dominance that can now never really be challenged.

Ask HN: Does YouTube recommand content based on your social media use?
text:
I've noticed that after I'm talking about a specific topic on a site like Reddit, I get recommendations for videos about it on Youtube, even though I only really use it for music, comedy and tutorials.

Is everything we do on other social medias used to recommend us Youtube videos?

title: Best IDE or editor with Code Formatting for JavaScript, HTML, and PHP?
text:
I'm curious what your favorite solutions are for working with code, ideally with built in automatic code indentation and not too heavy on CPU usage.

This has been a pain for me as a Sublime Text user. I noticed it has quirks that make indentation a problem and without ease of readability my productivity suffers tremendously since my work involves dealings with long nested functions.

Positioning of the product and create a category creator
text:
Positioning of a product is a critical play in your target market appreciating your product. Following are the five components of effective positioning as defined by April Dunford:

1. What are your Competitive Alternatives?

2. Unique capabilities that you have the that competition lacks

3. Benefit those features enable for the customer

4. Characteristics of the group of buyers that lead them to really care about the value you deliver.

5. Market category that defines and helps the customer understand your value

6. Lastly, relevant trends that target customers understand can help your product become more relevant.

An article on how to position your product to your customers is below: https://buildstartupinpublic.substack.com/p/how-to-pitch-your-product-to-your

An article on how to position a category creator is as below https://buildstartupinpublic.substack.com/p/what-you-need-to-know-if-you-are/comments
